title: A bag contains 5 red marbles, 8 white marbles, and 8 blue marbles. You draw 3 marbles out at random without replacement. What is the probability that exactly two marbles are red? - Quora

response.answer_text: Straightforward application of the hypergeometric distribution here. There are 5C2 = 10 ways to have two red marbles.There are 16C1 = 16 ways to have one non-red marble.There are 21C3 = 1330 ways to pull three marbles total. So the probability is 160/1330 = .12030075…. Let’s check our work in Excel:=HYPGEOM.DIST(2,3,5,21,FALSE)=0.12030075…….

red/red/non-red = 5/21 x 4/20 x 16/19 = 320/7980 = .04010025 non-red/red/red = 16/21 x 5/20 x 4/19 = 320/7980 = .04010025 red/non-red/red = 5/21 x 16/20 x 4/19 = 320/7980 = .04010025 So 3 x .04010025 = .12030075 = Slightly greater than a 12% chance of getting any combination of 3 red and one non-red marble.
